newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: PRESS DIGEST - New Zealand newspapers - May 7.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New Zealand newspapers - May 7.

text.p: Legal threat to cheap imports: Legal action by the American automotive giant Chrysler to prevent unauthorised sales of its vehicles in New Zealand could signal the beginning of the end for the imported used car industry.
Bolger expected to nudge Kohl on air services: The German Government is expected to come under gentle pressure from New Zealand this week to liberalise air services between the two countries.
Takeover pulls plug on porcelain: An Australian takeover has put an end to the manufacturer of porcelain toilet bowls and hand basins in New Zealand.
Rates fall on lower job numbers: Stalling jobs growth on Tuesday underpinned the market's view that the Reserve Bank will ease its stance in its June monetary policy statement.
Govt to review regulations: In a bid to minimise compliance costs, the government is to review the ways it draws up regulations and assesses their likely impact on the cost of doing business.

Sanford hopes to hook into better trading catches: Fishing group Sanford, which suffered in the first six months of its fiscal year from weak fish prices and a slump in the New Zealand dollar, expects trading conditions to continue to be difficult over coming months.
Woolworths coy on market share: Woolworths New Zealand is refusing to say how it is faring in the grocery market despite recording an increase on tax-paid trading profit of 11.7 percent last year.
No action on age rights breach: No remedy has been ordered by the Complaints Review Tribunal in the case of a proven breach of the Human Rights Act.
Donovan gets Zambian revenue job: A former Customs manager at Auckland Airport, Kevin Donovan, has been appointed Commissioner General of the Zambian Revenue Authority by President F.J.T. Chiluba.

Clear optimistic despite cloudy outlook for year: Clear Communications expects a continuation of tough market conditions to constrain financial performance in the current year, although a renewed assault on the market should see growth resume an upward track in a year's time.
